newsitem.title: INDIA: India playwright recalls horrors of partition.
newsitem.headline: India playwright recalls horrors of partition.

text.p: An Indian playwright on Thursday called the partition of British India 50 years ago and the slaughter of hundreds of thousands of people that followed possibly the greatest tragedy in history.

"The partition of India in 1947 remains perhaps the greatest tragedy in world history," Gursharan Singh, a left- wing Sikh Punjabi writer, told Reuters in this northern city as India and Pakistan celebrated a half century of freedom from colonial rule.
Singh was an 18-year-old in the Pakistani city of Multan on August 15, 1947, when largely Hindu India won independence.
Moslems had formed Pakistan a day earlier.
"Communal riots were going on. While my father decided to stay on in Multan, my mother, elder sister and I moved to Amritsar in a caravan of buses," Singh said.
At the city of Amritsar, just 100 km (62 miles) from the Pakistani city of Lahore, Hindus and Sikhs helped each other, but Moslems still remaining behind were targeted for attack.
"I was eyewitness to an incident when Moslem girls were forced to remove their clothes and paraded on the street at the instance of some Sikh leaders," Singh said.
"It was only when a group of Hindu and Sikh women lodged a strong protest that the Moslem girls were allowed to wear their clothes and return to their places."
As jam-packed trains ferried hundreds of thousands of people back and forth across the border, there were tales from both sides of religious bigotry and terrible deeds.
Historians say hundreds of thousands died during the partition that saw six million people cross a newly formed border. Many left for a new homeland carrying nothing but mournful memories.
Counting the dead was considered futile.
Conservative estimates put the number of killed in partition riots at 500,000. Others believe up to a million may have died.
At a refugee camp, young inhabitants in an unfamiliar city helped old people whose children had gone looking for a livelihood to faraway cities like Delhi, Singh recalled.

"Imagine, more than one million people were killed in the name of religion just because a small group of political leaders decided that there should be two countries instead of one united India," Singh said.
